comments.commentBody: From one Impoverished Gentlewoman to another: If you want to stay, great, but you can lead a more similar life than you imagine out here in the hinterlands. It's what I do, anyway. Loads of talented people, great libraries. The true downside is the lack of variety in restaurants, but since I can't afford them anyway, who cares?

I have a cat, a black and white. He's an indoor cat and I'm scared to death to let him escape outdoors. I don't think he's got enough smarts to figure out how to get back in the house.

All I could think is that maybe when Holly was out in the wilds she may have found a dead pigeon and ate some of it for food. We all know how the pigeon have tremendous homing instincts. Either that or she stayed at the Holiday Inn Express.

Kudos to Ms. Mazzola and her family for rescuing the weak and emaciated cat and -- and then being willing to check for a microchip and relinquish the animal they had become very attached to. I commend their kindness and generosity.

Thank goodness Holly had been micro-chipped!! Thank goodness for the people who feed the feral cats behind the restaurant, and for the kindness of people like Ms. Mazzola and her children, for rescuing Holly from perishing, and taking her to the vet. And thank goodness for the Richters for being such loving owners that Holly wanted to get home, no matter what. Holly is amazing.

When my cat Jessie was a bit younger, I took her for walks (on a harness and leash) around the neighborhood, which she loved to do. A couple of times she bolted out and down the fire escape, but never went so far away that she wouldn't (eventually) return when I called. Now I have moved to the other side of Chicago, and she hasn't been outside. I wonder what would happen if she somehow got out and got lost? (yes, she has a microchip)

A bone marrow transplant is a very different thing from a kidney transplant, certainly from a donor's perspective. A bone marrow donor goes through a minor procedure to harvest the bone marrow cells and his body is capable of making many new ones to replace the ones given away. A kidney donor has to undergo surgery with all the attendant risks of anesthesia and post operative complications and infections and he cannot regrow the kidney. Of course, a person can survive fine with just one kidney, but these two procedures are not equivalent. Moreover, how do you know your sister is a match if she hasn't even come forward to start the testing process?

Your facts are fine. The rationale for blocking blood donations has become very weak (and remains more because of the political implications of making the change, than the actual risk). The rationale for marrow, where exhaustive, individual testing can and will be done before the actual transplant, is even less rational, and even more offensive. In particular, marrow donation is a pre-planned event. A donor can refrain from risky behavior in advance of the donation, improving the reliability of (already very reliable) HIV tests.

Thank you for the informative comment. One correction: the registration is free of charge at marrow.org if you are between the ages of 18-44. It will cost a $100 donation (tax-deductible) to be added to the registry if you are between the ages of 45-60. The FAQs on the website explain why.

Even a satire and sarcasm makes meaning when grounded in reality, which seems missing here when, Obama is viewed as the liberal  Reagan or someone else, ignoring his real political persona that's symbiotically linked, both in vision and striving, with the American dream seen by the Founders.

With regard to inflation in Japan, a post over at Zero Hedge makes an interesting point. Currently, interest on Japan's debt consumes a significant fraction of tax revenues. The debt is so large that each 1 percent increase in bond rates will (as debt is rolled over) consume an additional 25 percent of revenues. Of course, bond rates reflect estimates of future inflation.

So, what happens when interest payments are larger than tax revenues, as may happen if there is appreciable inflation? Japan will be in the position of having to borrow *more* just to pay interest. This seems quite unstable to me. If this argument is correct, then even modest inflation will rapidly put Japan on a very steep downward slope.

The only ways out of this that I can see are:

1. Grow the economy so that those payments are manageable. But, this takes time, and is not guaranteed to work.

2. Seigniorage (or the digital equivalent) to buy back the debt. I am not sure if Japanese law will allow this.

So, all of you who are hoping for a bit of inflation in Japan, how about chiming in and point out where this argument is wrong.

The Republicans DO want to eliminate the New Deal. They have been trying to work around the harsh reality that a large portion of their voter base is old, white Social Security recipients by cutting future Social Security and Medicare benefits for people currently under 50.

To the Republicans' shock, many seniors don't share their philosophy of "I've got mine, so . . . intercourse the rest of you."

So Republicans are switching to the argument that we have to cut future Social Security and Medicare benefits in order to avoid having to make cuts in Social Security and Medicare benefits in the future.

The article describes the war of political posturing and uses of ideology and propaganda to enhance and harm causes, but behind these things there is reality.

There is an economy that does its own thing, collapsing in spite of propaganda that things were fine and recovering in spite of all the fear and uncertainty propaganda was able to create. As more and more people come out, it becomes harder to sell the idea that they have chosen their path and we should persuade them to reconsider by making that path as illegal and difficult as we can.

Economics does have a reality, which we have not yet mastered because we mask it too much with ideology. If the reality of economics is that more stimulus was needed, then more stimulus is needed. We should have a technical debate between people whose math is not rusty rather than a propaganda war between simplistic models whose adequacy is never discussed.

Before Obamacare, many people had to scramble for the health care they needed, with no guarantee they would get it. Each year some didnt and died. If any reliable source kept a count, it was not widely known and discussed. With Obamacare there will be fewer of these people. But health care will not be affordable in this country until we change the way it is paid for.

A liberal Reagan would have led on these reality issues. Obama has merely stopped the country's transformation into a richer Mexico/Argentina/Texas -- something new on the earth but not in a good way.
